replies.text:
@MattieK09
To start, we're arguing anecdotal stuff here, so take it for what it is. The 'I've personally seen this' arguement only goes so far.

As for fervent self loathing, it depends on your definition. Annouced self loathing of the type in this post might be more apparent in the left, as you see it. If I go to 4-chan or 8-chan though, I'll find plenty of clinical examples of self hatred commiserating under the guise of 'It's their fault!'. 

There also exist online incel communities whose goal is to tell other incels why they'll never get laid. Other incels go there specifically for the self flagellation, which perpetuates the cycle. PS: credit to Contrapoints.

Further, one tactic used by the group 'Life after Hate' is showing those who want to leave that they really aren't inherent failures, that there are other (if you're lucky) options besides hating the dude or dudette next to you.

Is there self announced loathing along the right? Probably not. Like most groups, they act like a locust swarm; if you don't tow the line you get eaten. The kind of self assessment seen here gets deemed as weakness PDQ, pretty much everywhere. I mean, there's a reason the VA has to push so hard to get vets into counseling, and why suicide rates are so high among them.

replies.author: @jamesgiesea6743
replies.text:
@MattieK09 
Ouch.

Urmm... if you believe your claim clearly showcased obvious expression, then I'd recommend taking some debate courses. Stating it relates to the original video without adding context generates miscommunications like this.

As for your examples of left, I haven't ignored them per se. I've specifically asked why they mattered. If they both present self-loathing, why does the expression among the left matter? Are you making a claim that proclaimed self loathing is a variant of virtue signalling?

Side note: I'm deliberately avoiding  going through your specific examples for two reasons: 1) the false equivalence deviates from your original point, that leftists expressing self loathing is somehow a bad thing, and 2) going down that rabbit hole starts an endless debate about the human condition that this post can't possibly handle.

As for my being vet, believe what you will. By all means tell those that investigate it. They'll ask for my DD-214, then tell you to move on.

I have served four years in the Marine Corps infantry, from '93 to '97, and lucked out. You're right, I don't have no combat experience. My unit didn't serve in a combat theater during that time, and no other veteran ever thought less of me for it. They have, in fact, commiserated with a fellow vet, over a drink in god knows how many bars, in VA waiting rooms, and in group counseling sessions, how there own experiences effected them and their families.

Maybe this should end though. If you'd ignore the 'Life after Hate' example, defend your statement by claiming 'so does the left', and define what a real vet would do based solely on combat experience, I'm not sure I'll be able to get though to you. Have a great day. This debate has been enlightening.

replies.text:
@ZoomahZoomah Yeah I researched it. I know he acknowledges that climate change is happening but believes that human activity being the main cause is overblown/the effects won't be as bad as scientists are making it out to be. He's still wrong.

To be honest, I find a lot of his writing hard to reconcile with itself, as though he states a belief or a counterpoint firmly and then never bothers to elaborate on its deeper implication. His evolving views on climate change are a good example of this, like when he tries to balance negatives with positives (arguing that human activity can shift inland and benefit heartland economies like agriculture or mining) that display a only cursory knowledge of the topic (he doesn't seem to know that heartlands will be hit hard by droughts and soil erosion).

My anger at him actually follows through on that idea - because of this awkwardness with large-scale thinking, Shapiro likes to compress all of his ideas in snappy rejoinders. He strikes me as someone who was an excellent debater in college, and mistook the theater of political debate as a substitute for serious, rigorous, interrogative reflection on ideas (including his own). He's usually very good at bringing up the only points he needs to sound like he has an airtight argument, but the 'sell your houses' clip stood out to me as a Yogi Berra-type line.

Mr. Shapiro does not think, he merely performs thought, and gave an underwhelming performance at that.

https://www.ipcc.ch/
The IPCC reports are also worth reading. If you look beyond the "summery for policy makers" you might start to see the actual cost of attempting to reduce global temperatures.
The climate is changing
Our activities contribute to those changes
There will be an impact on humanity in the long term
We will adapt to those changes
Individual human resourcefulness, ingenuity and will are more likely to provide these solutions than government's.

That said, I agree with you that he gives a narrow and sometimes surface level take on some subjects and I am aware of how partisan he is. He's a fawed individual like the rest of us but on the subject of climate change we need lots of people looking at the problem from many angles. replies.author: @ZoomahZoomah
replies.text:
@hustler3of4culture3 individual cases or "your own experience" don't give you a broad view of a system. You can't draw conclusions from these things because we are subject to your own experiences and bias. How you personally see things is only representative of how you personally see things.

What would it take for police bias to manifest itself in a conviction?

1. A police officer or offices would have to be bias and a false allegation would need to be made.
2. Their superior officers would have to be complicit or unaware.
3. False evidence would need to be manufactured
4. the crown prosecution would need to believe this false evidence and allow the case to go to court
5. The accused legal representation would need to be unable or unwilling to disprove the false allegations and or question the false evidence
6. The judge or jury would need to believe the false allegations and the false evidence beyond a reasonable doubt and convict.

There are so many people involved in this process. There are so many checks and balances to ensure that no one, as far as reasonably possible, is convicted of a crime they did not commit.

As a side note. You said: "see through your white eyes".
How is my race relevant to this conversation? Can you make assumptions about me based on my race?

*Oh my god, that ending:*
"... democracies fail when citizens stop believing in the legitimacy of democratic institutions and even if we are able to protect ourselves from extremist elements, what is currently hollowing-out our institutions is the encroaching oligarchy which the US and Germany are struggling to ward-off.
Maintaining a democracy is constant struggle and one that sometimes requires being realistic instead of idealistic. I would love to live in a world where ideals and Voltaire quotes were all that mattered but history demands we put facts over feelings. And the fact is that: pointing-out to your countrymen that he is committing the "naturalistic fallacy" won't prevent him from bulldozing your body into an open mass grave because he deems you inferior. In the same vein, it is also a fantasy to think people who have the power to bend democracy to their will, won't use that power given the opportunity. Extremists break the marketplace of ideas because they don't play by its rules; the same way the rich can bypass it entirely for their own benefit.
If we want to keep our freedoms and our ability to self-govern, we should not just view the Richard Spencers of the world as anti-democratic threats but also the Kochs, the Mercers and everyone else who is able to replace a good argument, with money." DAMN, I'm so using this.

What can we currently do to reduce or reverse climate change and what price would we pay?
Is it possible or viable to stop climate change or do we need to look at adapting to the changing climate and (for example) move away from low lying regions?
China and India are the biggest polluters and are both increasing their production of pollutants. Whereas we, in the west pollute less and are reducing our emmisions. What should we do about China and india?

Does asking these questions make me a climate change denier?

replies.author: @varana
replies.text:
Us versus them.
You have to have a following with a strong tribal sense; "we're in this together, and _the other_ is the enemy". Whatever "the enemy" does and says, is probably aimed against you, and probably made up for that reason.
You have to create overwhelming mistrust in any sources and people other than the ones that you approve.
If your following doesn't trust anyone really, they will tend to trust only those who are already affirming their world view, without you doing anything, because being challenged is hard.
If you can find a few actual snippets and mistakes to "prove" your mistrust of opposing sources, esp. if it's in a field where you need experts to understand it, or there are some very valid concerns in your followers' lives, you're in a very strong position to reinforce the tribal sense of community and the general mistrust of the outside.

There's a general tendency that the divisions of "us versus them" - Democrats vs Republicans, "liberals" vs "conservatives", left-wing vs right-wing, and so on, are becoming deeper. These divisions can be exploited by people with an actual interest in certain economic areas (like coal), with an interest in power (like someone trying to get elected), or with an interest in related political fields (people accepting human-made climate change are typically also in favour of policies X, Y, and Z which you oppose, so to widen your base against X, Y, and Z, you adopt climate change into your portfolio). And then you find inconsistencies in the scientific process and spread that to your followers, and you find actual socioeconomic issues like areas hit by deindustrialisation and the loss of jobs in the coal (or oil, or whatever) sector.
Voil√†, modern climate change scepticism.

replies.author: @MonMalthias
replies.text:
@ultrasonic22 
The US is the world's second largest emitter so any reductions that do happen are beneficial even if developing countries overtake it.

The idea that the Iron law of economic policy will always win out against environmental policy is only true to the extent that the economic policy being pursued right now is high carbon. Fracking receives numerous tax breaks and low-interest government loans precisely because it has enabled the USG, in turn, to have a hand on the lever on international oil markets. It was also responsible for destroying the coal industry in the CONUS - the emissions reductions that allowed the US to surpass its (never ratified) Kyoto targets were largely due to fracking and also the 2008 GFC.

But it does not have to be that way.

A state-led effort to embark on an American equivalent of a Messmer plan (I suppose it would be Atoms for Peace 2.0) would decarbonise basically all of the US, reduce air pollution down to a bare minimum (the next largest polluter, transport, would then be dominant), and displace fracked gas on the power grid. It would _not,_ unlike a 100% renewables grid, result in undue expansion of land use, mining, or reduction in apex predators. Mining in particular would have to explode in output to keep up with the need for rare earths, heavy metals, copper, and concrete for basemats and foundations. 

The revival of a heavy industry like nuclear would bring back to some extent, a working class that has had to endure decades of austerity and disenfranchisement from wage growth; as well as industry offshoring.

Which is to say it would never happen. Greens would be apoplectic that nuclear power is even considered. Market liberals despise state intervention. Conservatives love nuclear power but oppose state driven efforts to do...anything. And those on the left have either been supportive of what nuclear energy represents - emancipation of the land from exploitation for energy - or quite sceptical of it's historically male-dominated workforce, strict heirarchy, and historical violations of native people's land rights, health and safety. But it _would_ address climate change while not burdening the economy with energy austerity.

replies.text:
@ZoomahZoomah ¬†@Adam¬† no one has responded to your comment as far as i can see so I'll take it point by point (hopefully) briefly.

1. As far as science can tell pretty much all of current climate change is man made, based on the natural cycles of warming and cooling of the planet by the earth's changes in orbit and tilt we should actually be in a period of cooling, likewise the degree of warming we've experienced within the timeframe of the last 100-150 years is incomparable to any observed rate of change in all of the earth's history

2. We can build more nuclear plants in the first world, block tax breaks/subsidies/grants to fossil fuel industries, put those funds back towards renewable developments and updating our energy infrastructure, and develop carbon capture and reforestation projects. The costs for this up front will be large, the low ball projections for the costs of dealing with climate change are many times larger than these initiatives so short term high cost, mid term technically profitable, long term neutral (financially speaking of course, if speaking of social costs or costs to well being and lifestyle these are negligible to take action and massive with inaction)

3. China and India are the most rapidly industrializing nations - right now - but the US has put out more pollution into the world than any other nation directly on its own even if you just start counting from 1900, and our industrial record goes back past that. The first world already industrialized it is ludicrous to assert we can or should stop other nations from doing so, though I am certainly in favor of the first world providing direct, no strings attached aid in speeding up this process past its most egregious phases where more places can employ nuclear and renewables effectively.
Lastly it can't be understated that India and China's pollution is in part the first world's as most of their industry is in service to those nations or part of the value chain of those nation's companies. IE they are polluting for us

It does not. It may make you a "climate skeptic" but hopefully with the basic information presented to you that may change as the position of the skeptic is simply one of ignorance, not in the condescending way simply that the information hasn't been in your life to observe.
If you deny the validity of the science then you are a denier.
If you don't deny the science and support "alternative solutions" like eugenics and cleansings then you would be a monster.

replies.text:
@jashinftw It's not a downplay at all. 

"[...] both Social Democracy and fascism are agents of monopoly capitalism; both fight tooth and nail against the struggle of the working class for its social emancipation. With this as their aim, both disrupt and weaken working-class organisations.

Their methods are, however, different. While fascism smashes the class organisations of the working class from without and opposes their whole basis and counters them with an alternative ‚Äònational‚Äô ideology, Social Democracy undermines them from within by diverting them along reformist bourgeois channels. Whereas fascism relies mainly on coercion, along with deception, Social Democracy relies mainly on deception, along with coercion. Their aims are identical; only their methods differ.
[...]
Social Democracy emerged from the First World War with the twin aims of defeating the working-class revolution and helping to reconstruct the badly-battered structure of capitalism. It performed both these shameful tasks very well indeed. No crime was too much for it, no depths too low for it to stoop to, in defeating the revolution - the murder of leading revolutionaries, the incarceration of thousands of others, the wholesale repression of many more thousands still. It assumed governmental responsibility and undertook the shooting down of the most militant workers, secured some concessions and pacified large sections in the interests of saving the skin of finance capital."

http://marxism.halkcephesi.net/harpal%20Brar/bourgeois%20democracy%20and%20fascism.htm

replies.author: @transsylvanian9100
replies.text:
@jashinftw "The sapping of the German working-class will to resist had been effected not by fascism but by Social Democracy, whose leadership was treating the prospect of a Nazi government in a favourable light. Thus, in April 1932, Severing went on record as saying: ‚ÄúThe Social Democratic Party no less than the Catholic Party, is strongly inclined to see Herr Hitler‚Äôs Nazis share the government responsibility‚Äù (quoted in R Palme Dutt, p.127).

[...] Social Democracy eagerly resorted to the plea that now Hitler had a ‚Äúdemocratic mandate‚Äù it was not justifiable to oppose him save as a ‚Äúloyal parliamentary opposition‚Äù. Taking parliamentary cretinism to its logical absurdity of supporting a fascist terrorist regime because it had a majority in Parliament, albeit a rigged majority secured at the point of a bayonet in elections held under terror, Stampfen, the former editor of¬†Vorw√§rts, wrote:

‚ÄúThe victory of the government parties makes it possible to govern strictly in accordance with the Constitution.

‚ÄúThey have only to act as a legal government, and it will follow naturally that we shall be a legal opposition; if they choose to use their majority for measures that remain within the framework of the Constitution, we shall confine ourselves to the role of their fair critics.¬†‚Äù

For his part, Kautsky, at one time the leader of the Second International and considered the best theoretician of Marxism after Engels‚Äô death, but long since degenerated and gone totally rotten, wrote:

‚ÄúThe dictatorship has the mass of the population behind it.¬†‚Äù

Beginning with opportunism on the questions of the tasks of the proletarian revolution in regard to the bourgeois state, through his support for the imperialist First World War and his opposition to the proletarian revolution in Russia, he had rolled down to the bottom and into the gutter, writing pieces embellishing the Hitlerite regime as founded on mass support.

W N Ewer, diplomatic correspondent of the¬†Daily Herald, wrote that Hitler‚Äôs triumph was ‚Äú‚Ä¶ a victory for democracy,¬†‚Äù for he had ‚Äúcome to power by the most strictly constitutional means ‚Ä¶ Of course there was a certain amount of intimidation. There always is ‚Ä¶ The figures indeed are proof that the election was practically free‚Äù (‚ÄòWhy Hitler Triumphed‚Äô,¬†Plebs, April 1933, quoted in R Palme Dutt,¬†op. cit. p.128).

An exactly similar view was expressed by Maxton, the Chairman of the Independent Labour Party:

In this way Social Democracy attempted to cover its subservience to fascism by the barely-disguised device of first ignoring the conditions of terror under which the election of 5 March was held, and then use this mockery of an election as providing a legitimate mandate for the fascist regime.

Social Democracy‚Äôs disgraceful, degrading and despicable line was to continue after the election in a vain attempt to curry favour with fascism. The speech of the Social Democratic leader, Wels, at the opening of the Reichstag on 23 March, was an important expression of this line. He, as the leader of the party, openly resigned form the Executive Committee of the Second International, accusing the latter of spreading ‚Äúatrocity stories‚Äù against the fascists. The leadership of the trade unions declared its readiness to co-operate with the Nazis, hailed in their press as the fascist ‚Äúrevolution‚Äù, as a triumphant ‚Äúcontinuation of the 1918 revolution‚Äù. It stressed that the common enemy was communism, and that their ‚Äòsocialism‚Äô was a ‚ÄúGerman affair‚Äù (Sozial Demokratischer Pressedient, 9 March, 1933, quoted by R Palme Dutt,¬†op. cit. p.129). Reaching the depths of degradation and treachery to the working class, on this basis, the central executive committee of the trade unions gave an official call to the workers to participate in Hitler‚Äôs May Day.

‚ÄúThe trade union leaders have sealed their reconciliation with the new rulers of Germany,‚Äù wrote the¬†Daily Herald¬†of 24 April 1933.

The attempt by the reformists of Social Democracy to play the role of a recognised tolerated adjunct to fascism failed, in part owing to the fact that a huge number of workers in the big factories rejected their leaders‚Äô calls and stayed away from the Nazi May Day parades. Once it was crystal clear that the Social-democratic leadership‚Äôs grip on the workers was inadequate to serve fascist ends, straight away on 2 May, the Nazis seized the unions, amalgamated them into their own labour front, marched their leaders into prison, and in their place appointed Nazi functionaries.

‚ÄúThe Leiparts and the Grassmanns‚Äù, declared Dr Ley, the leader of the Nazi Labour front, ‚Äúmay profess their devotion to Hitler; but they are better in prison‚Äù (quoted in R Palme Dutt,¬†op. cit.¬†p.129).

For its part, the Social Democratic Party traversed the same path of humiliation, degradation and capitulation, followed by dissolution. On 17 May all its members in the Reichstag voted for the fascist government‚Äôs resolution and joined in unanimous acclamation of Hitler. Much good did this grovelling do for them! All the property of the Social Democratic Party was confiscated, and on 22 June the organisation itself was declared ‚Äòdissolved‚Äô.

With this, Social Democracy was compelled by the bourgeoisie to continue its disruptive work in the conditions of illegality - conditions in which it could be of greater use to the ruling class in the event of a revolutionary upheaval than if it were to closely and openly identified with fascism."

replies.text:
At an extremely precarious time when Germany had just lost a massive war, had soldiers still abroad, famine on its way, the SPD was given the authority to form a new government specifically so reactionary forces could later hang them out to dry...

That time Rosa Luxemburg thought was ideal to throw out her previous theorising about bringing about socialism peacefully and instead started fomenting civil war. She even started a newspaper for that explicit purpose. And, not to forget, if you go by election results from the time she also did not have a majority of popular support behind her revolution. 

"Civil war is just another word for class struggle and the thought of implementing socialism without class struggle by a parliamentary majority is a ridiculous petit-bourgeois Illusion."

So the SPD tried to stop a brewing civil war, especially under the impressions of the terror of civil war and revolution going on in Russia at the time, while not actually having control over the military. That all collapsed due to the end of WW1. So the SPD tenously allied itself with the only game in town, reactionary left-over military units, basically "rogue" military, which was a shitty thing to do. And those murdered Luxemburg and Liebknecht, which was a horrific crime. But not really a surprise for the thought leaders of one side in a civil war.

Anyway TL;DR: A lot more than just "dissent"

author: @VerboseMinimalist
text:
I agree with what you're saying about the limitations US government power, as opposed to "private" power, being used to regulate hate speech. I just wanted to add a bit of context about the SPLC and the role of nonprofit organizations in the US political system, at the risk of telling you something you might already know.

My main issue with your analysis is referring to these groups as "private sector" organizations, but this might just be a cultural/linguistic difference. In the US, the phrase "private sector" is used almost exclusively to refer to for-profit companies and entities that do not have providing public services as a primary part of their mission statement, whereas the "public sector" refers to governmental entities. However, the "nonprofit sector" is quite different in its social and economic role in the US and refers to charitable organizations. It includes everything from the Red Cross to the National Rifle Association.

The SPLC is a 501(c)3 charitable organization, referring to the legal code for the tax-exempt status conferred on charities. These groups "must be organized and operated exclusively for exempt purposes set forth in section 501(c)(3), and none of its earnings may inure to any private shareholder or individual. In addition, it may not be an action organization, i.e., it may not attempt to influence legislation as a substantial part of its activities and it may not participate in any campaign activity for or against political candidates." They are also legally required to collect as much donor information as possible and to disclose all that information and their complete financial reports for each fiscal year. (Source: https://www.irs.gov/charities-non-profits/charitable-organizations/exemption-requirements-section-501c3-organizations)

SPLC reported an operating budget of just over $44 million and nearly $450 million in total assets for FY 2017 (Source: https://www.splcenter.org/sites/default/files/103117_afs.pdf) This arguably makes SPLC a mid-sized charity by US standards, with the largest foundations dwarfing these numbers by an order of magnitude (Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_wealthiest_charitable_foundations). The median salary for nonprofit CEOs is $123,000 annually in 2014, though there were 76 organizations with CEO compensation over $500,000, including 10 that were over $1 million. (Source: https://d20umu42aunjpx.cloudfront.net/2016+CEO+Comp+Study/2016+CEO+Compensation+Study.pdf)

The nonprofit sector is vital to the functionality of society in the US, as the federal government and many state governments are loathe to allocate funds for and/or to directly provide social services, as I'm sure you know. I just felt the need to add this context for anyone who cares. Again, I'm sorry if I'm repeating stuff that people already know and for the long comment, but this distinction is quite salient to the understanding the functions of US society.

Big fan here. Keep up the great work!

‚Äã@iantodoyle7876 It is very hard to make valid criticisms of Peterson because he rarely says anything falsifiable .

Whenever he said something like that thou, he is  almost always lying or wrong.

The most simple thing to point is the fact that he constantly uses correlations and talks about them as if they are causality.

Another thing is the fact that he constantly references books which he most likely never read (judging by the volume of misquoting he does).  For instance, he most certainly never read Marx (not that I am a fan, I am just trying to be honest) 

He also  holds this weird opinion that if men who are not capable of finding a woman lose all stake in society and they become violent.  He says that because he is using one of the most annoying fallacies - the idea that you can tell a reasonably sounding evolutionary tale about how things would work if we followed evolutionary principles and by that you will be doing science. 
That's bullshit. And also the study he shared on the topic disagreed with him. So I guess he never even fucking read it. The study concluded that if you differentiate men on the amount of sex they are having, there aren't less violent men than the people who never had sex. (We are talking about adult men, it's not a statistical issue brought by the fact that they are also selecting kids)

While JP maybe quite knowledgable in psychology, he is in not law

replies.author: @harrythej9683
replies.text: @scottsbarbarossalogic3665 It does more than that. It makes institutions liable for potential discrimination by employees, which is why Peterson was warned by his university. It clearly had an effect in that sense already. Also, it has not yet been ruled that "misgendering" is not hate speech, while people have argued for it to be viewed that way. As long as there is no definite ruling, criticizing ideology might still be illegal and the article just believes it to be unlikely, not impossible or implausible.

replies.author: @scottsbarbarossalogic3665
replies.text:
Harry the J¬† Instutions being liable for discrimination based other criteria(sex, race, religion, etc)is present within the Canadian Human Rights Act.  But that discrimination is defined as "to deny services, employment, accommodation and similar benefits to individuals, based on their identity(sex, race, religion,  etc), to matters within federal jurisdiction, such as the federal government, federal services to the public, or a federally regulated industry."  The University of Toronto talked to JP about his conduct because he was being an asshole, which is not illegal, but does probably break their code of conduct.  It would go againist the CRHA if JP refused to teach someone based on their gender expression; an action which should be illegal, just as it is with sex, race, religion, etc.

Because the bill amended an existing legislation, it gets all of the ruling of that legislation; Hatred, and therefore Hate Speech as an act of performing Hatred, in regards to the Criminal Code and the Canadian Bill of Rights, is defined as "predicated on destruction, and hatred against identifiable groups therefore thrives on insensitivity, bigotry and destruction of both the target group and of the values of our society.  ¬†Hatred in this sense is a most extreme emotion that belies reason; an emotion that, if exercised against members of an identifiable group, implies that those individuals are to be despised, scorned, denied respect and made subject to ill-treatment on the basis of group affiliation."(R v Keegstra, Chief Justice Dickson). So using a racial slur, or intentionally misgendering someone, would not be considered Hate Speech (though maybe hateful in the non-legal sense), but calling for the death of all black people, or teaching your students that there is a vast conspiracy Jews out to destroy the world, for example, do fall under Hatred.

Which article?

The points I would like to make are that he wasn't "being an asshole", as he uses people's preferred pronoun if asked in person, but opposes it being compelled by law. Also, the article which explained that misgendering was unlikely to be considered hate speech presented a legal opinion, as there has not been any case dealing with it yet. replies.text:
Small states having proportionately more power is in and of itself not a bad thing. The EU parliament does something similar called "degressive proportionality" meaning the larger the state the  "worse" the representation so that smaller states don't get steamrolled. At the extreme ends that means one German MEP represents ca 850,000 people while one Maltese MEP represents ca. 75,000 IIRC.

The problem in the USA is that the electoral college has no proportionality at all and concentrates power in one person instead of spreading it around an entire parliament.

I see the EC as a pointless middleman. There are 340 million Americans. It shouldn't matter what state you live in when voting on the national level. It also flips votes in states that are winner-take-all. An example is my state, Ohio. Trump won something like 51% of the state, but gets all the EC votes, essentially flipping everyone who didnt vote for him. My vote for Jill Stein basically didn't matter....that that it would matter anyway. Part of the problem with the 2 state party is they determine who can even participate in the debates, with Stein and Gary Johnson being left out entirely. As others have pointed out, this means we can have a very lively debate in the box created by the two broken parties (the Democrats suffering a schism after Bernie Sanders was screwed by the DNC in favor of Clinton, with the progressives vs the corporate centrists, and the various factions within the GOP at odds with each other, from the Alt right to Christian fundamentalists to the Ancaps in the "libertarian" party/section). Representative democracy (if you even want to call it democracy) can only work if the representatives do the job they were elected to do: represent their consituents. 
Instead, it looks like top-down concentrated government cannot help but corrupt people, like Tolkien's "one ring", and we are left with illusions of democracy while a democratically elected aristocracy tries to balance public interest with their own interests.

But as the example of Germany shows, States cannot be trusted to carry out this vital duty. It then falls upon us to oppose those who preach intolerance, starting with Nazis and fascists. Edit: Let me add that opposition to the intolerant includes violence if necessary. With fascists and Nazis, it often is.

replies.author: @tristanband4003
replies.text:
@C.1212-c4d I would argue that this in-group identification is a product of being made a national outgroup. I forget, but there was a study done on this. It argued that among Muslim immigrants (a broad swath that spans from Southeast Asia, the Middle East, and Africa), esp their children, the tendency toward in-group identification was related to their ability to take part in their host country's life (seeking employment, education, meeting people and making friends, travel, generally feeling welcome, etc). 

As I mention here in America with the Irish, that is exactly what we saw. When we did everything we could to push them away, they turned inward. We saw the same with Latin American and South American immigrants as well. Believe it or not, prior to 9/11, Middle Easterners were integrating into the US quite well. Then the witch hunts and villification started. We reap what we have sewn, and I do not want to see Europe make the same mistake. Pushing immigrants away only serves to turn the most dire outcomes into self-fulfilling prophecies.

Another lesson from America: it is a fools errand to control immigration. Nothing really controls the flow of immigration apart from how well your country is doing economically. Only thing quotas do is push more of it underground. If your country has economic opportunity, people will get in by hook or by crook. Trying to hold it back is like trying to hold back a river. Even dams work by re-directing water flow. And people are more uncontrollable than water.

I won't lie and say it will be easy. It won't. Nor will it be free of violence and bloodshed along the way. It won't. Watch Gangs of New York when you get the chance. While it is a movie, reality wasn't too far off. That's how bad it was along the way in assimilating the Irish. What we have the benefit of hindsight; use it. The less you fight it, the more you facilitate it, the faster the violent phase can be gotten through.

In addition, as they change, so too will your countries change. No, rest assured most do not want Sharia (apart from jobs, they usually come to get away from that too). But expect African and Middle Eastern food to become part of the national palette, mosques to become common as churches and synagogues, and for words to be loaned in both directions.

Another thing to accept; assimilation will never be 100%.

replies.author: @iz2333
replies.text:
People always misuse biology for this. *Race is not real*

If you look at the how biologists classify organisms, there's two ways. One is based on differences in morphology, the old way and too superficial. The other, the more modern method, is based on actual genetic differences. 

Races are a construct by people, who just saw other people, that looked different. They put them into different groups, because they didn't know better back then.

This is not the case anymore, modern technology allows us to compare the genetic codes of different organisms. A black man does *NOT* have different genes from a white man. They may have *genetic variations*, but they're the same species, they don't carry other different genes otherwise they wouldn't be able to reproduce. They only carry variations of the same genes which cause different expressions 

It's a myth that "Race is biology", race realism is a pseudoscientific attempt to make racism seem more viable.

replies.author: @iz2333
replies.text: @Doven Ro Galus Who is a black guy then? The issue is that this is not a real classification. There is no specific "black" or "white" gene, it' all based on the way people look to other people and that's not a natural classification at all.

replies.author: @iz2333
replies.text:
@Doven Ro Galus As you said, there is just an extremely tiny genetic difference between humans and chimps. Just tiny differences already make new species, just logically speaking, if the genetic make up of human "races" was different, then those human races wouldn't be the same species. 

Genetics aren't easy and I'm not the best in explaining things in english, so i suggest that you do some research on different genes/alleles and also on evolutionary taxonomy. I'll probably be a lot clearer what I mean then.

We don't all have exactly the same DNA, but the differences in varation and expression are not the same as the differences in genes between humans and apes. 

There is no such thing as a race specific gene, if there is, then please present one. Haplogroups for example, aren't a distiction for races, two white guys can have different haplogroups and a black and a white guy can have the same.

Races are made up terms based on peoples skin color and morphology.

author: @skelly790
text:
"Unlimited tolerance must lead to the disappearance of tolerance. If we extend unlimited tolerance even to those who are intolerant, if we are not prepared to defend a tolerant society against the onslaught of the intolerant, then the tolerant will be destroyed, and tolerance with them.‚ÄîIn this formulation, I do not imply, for instance, that we should always suppress the utterance of intolerant philosophies; as long as we can counter them by rational argument and keep them in check by public opinion, suppression would certainly be most unwise. But we should claim the right to suppress them if necessary even by force; for it may easily turn out that they are not prepared to meet us on the level of rational argument, but begin by denouncing all argument; they may forbid their followers to listen to rational argument, because it is deceptive, and teach them to answer arguments by the use of their fists or pistols. We should therefore claim, in the name of tolerance, the right not to tolerate the intolerant."
Karl Popper

To be honest, I don‚Äôt think the ‚Äúyelling fire in a crowded theater‚Äù argument is really one that touches the concept of free speech. 

You can yell fire all you want, the speech is perfectly protected.

What isn‚Äôt protected is knowingly endangering people. If your vocal chords are the tool you used for that, it doesn‚Äôt change the fact that what you‚Äôre being accosted for is the endangerment.

Similarly, being charged with a crime because you‚Äôre dancing behind the wheel of a car isn‚Äôt a ‚Äúdancing‚Äù regulation but a vehicular regulation. The dancing on its own is fine, what you‚Äôre accosted for is distracted driving.

author: @andiedandie25
text:
I have one small critique.

While it is possible to amend the Constitution, it is incredibly difficult to do so. I'm not too familiar with the Weimar Republic's constitution, but in the US case it takes an overwhelming majority of state legislatures to ratify the constitution, not a simple majority of the American population. In 200 odd years it's only been done 27 times.

Respecting, protecting and promoting the rights of Palestinian refugees to return to their homes and properties as stipulated in UN resolution 194." The claim to a so-called "right of return" for Palestinian refugees from the 1948 war *and their descendants* (who now number in the millions) is almost universally understood as advocating for a so-called "One-State" solution. I don't want to get into a legal or ethical argument about how to interpret resolution 194, but it is pretty clear that the movement seeks to eliminate Israel as a Jewish State.  You misrepresented this fact at the 10:45 mark. Of course, one can argue that states ought to be completely neutral with respect to the rights of their citizens, but that is certainly not the case elsewhere in the Arab world (or, for that matter, in much of Europe).

author: @warrendriscoll350
text: Random thought. I'd say that the free marketplace of ideas only makes sense to the extent that it promotes truth in discourse, and doesn't make sense if it drives us away from truth. Consequently, such a concept is not an intrinsic good, but an instrumental good. We can go further, and say that free marketplace of ideas is a bastardisation of what we're actually after, a scientific proving system of ideas, like peer review. Both systems are 100% about free speech. But they still work way differently. The latter still ends up suppressing hate based positions, since such positions have no logical support, and the former is always allowed to be corrupted by money, because it's a marketplace, and therefore always about purchasing power.

Do you honestly believe that everyone is stupid so we need to determine the "truth" for them? 
And you can't compare "peer" reviewed papers to regulating speech because one concerns itself with fact checking whilst the other concerns itself with censoring the "wrong" opinion.

replies.author: @warrendriscoll350
replies.text:
I'll respond point by point.

Regulated freedom is possible. Thinking otherwise would make you more anarchist than an anarchist. Though, regulation can prevent freedom.

The truth cannot be determined by any authority. Consequently, asking who shall determine the truth leads us down a blind alley.

When it comes to politics, everyone seems united in stupidity. I would say everyone would benefit from learning truth seeking techniques such as logic and empiricism.

Indeed, one concerns itself primarily with fact checking and the other primarily with censorship. Which is why we need to move away from a marketplace model. Or censorship of money or popularity will remain the dominant paradigm.

I also think that banning nazi literature such as "Mein Kampf" is a strategic mistake : it gives this text a sort of mystical aura, as if it contained a forbidden arcane... whereas it's actually extremely stuffy, boring and preposterous, and would probably appear so even to a racist far-right leaning reader.

author: @EpicKekzZ666
text: I'm insanely late to the party, but I just wanted to point out in regards to the statement at 13:00 that holocaust denial isn't an opinion to begin with. Opinions, as protect by Art. 5 I of our constitution, are statements, value judgements and so on (see BVerfGE 90, 247; 124, 300). Facts can be protected by thee freedom of opinion if they are used to form an opinion. Proven wrong facts however are NOT PROTECTED by that article. Freedom of opinion is an fundamental human right with the function of exchanging arguments, expressing your thoughts in said "marketplace of ideas". The expressing of WRONG(!) facts cannot contribute anything to that opinion building and argument exchange. Therefore, a law that bans holocaust denial (mind that ¬ß 130 III StGB has more preconditions than just "denying that holocaust") doesn't interefere with the freedom of opinion at all.

author: @wingflanagan
text:
I am always fascinated by your videos - even when I disagree. A real, fact-based discussion is something we need more of, instead of the tribal name-calling we have fallen into. If I may politely disagree on one theme - I believe you are too optimistic about our ability as a country to somehow arrive at reasonable solutions. Your criticism of the Koch brothers and the undue influence of money on politics is spot on. And while I think climate change is a real thing, the Right's criticism of some on the Left seeing it as a means of advancing a decidedly non-Capitalist financial agenda is also quite true.  BOTH sides have politicized the issue to the point where the average voter is frightened to vote either way. Do I want corporate greed or do I want to be taxed to death? What a lousy choice to have to make.  I don't expect to change your mind, and your command of the facts is probably superior to mine, but in my heart of hearts, I believe it's true, because it is human nature to wield both facts and lies as cudgels much like the proto-humans at the start of "2001: A Space Odyssey" wielded the bones of animals in a fight over the water hole. That's us. That's a fact. All else being equal both things can be true - both the political Right and the political Left (as defined in the US) are on the wrong side of things. The reasonable folks who think that both sides can have the occasional good idea and would like to use what works (as opposed to what The Party espouses) are squeezed out in their vice-like grip.


All that said (sorry for the rant!) I do appreciate your work and very much enjoy watching/listening. You deliver a lot of food for thought. Thanks!

replies.author: @Revelwoodie
replies.text:
LGBTQ Conservative:  Well, firstly, I would suggest you might be making the mistake of looking at social/political structures and economic structures as separate things.  They aren't.  The government is always involved in the economy, by definition, because the government is (or should be) the agent of the people, and people are obviously part of the economy.  Even by not "intervening" in the economy at all, the government is making a choice about how the interests of people are represented in their economy.  So every choice the government makes, or refrains from making, has economic impact.  To paraphrase Geddy Lee, If you choose not to intervene in the economy, you still have intervened in the economy.

Secondly, now that you're studying macroeconomics, I suggest you focus sharply on the distinction between private and public goods.  There are huge sections of our economy that are just structurally not suited to private sector control.  There will never be a way to make a profit building roads, maintaining a military, educating poor children, protecting the environment, or giving healthcare to the elderly and indigent.  Yet those things are at the beating heart of our economy.  That's what government is for.  In fact, I would state that even more strongly -- the very purpose of government is to intervene in the economy.  The alternative is anarcho-capitalism.  So called "crony capitalism" is just a political dysfunction.  If that's your concern, we need to focus on getting the money out of politics, not getting the politicians out of the economy.

As for military, education, and healthcare we do most of those now with Private security companies, private schools, and our current healthcare system. Then for schools I think private schools are better because they are more beholden to parents because parents want the best for their children and would remove their child from a private school that doesn't provide the education that was promised, though having public education run by the government would be fine if parents who don't send their children to public schools didn't have to pay for them in taxes. The healthcare system in the US is ok, but could use some work, personally I think a dual option would be better where there is a single-payer system, but people can opt-out if they don't want to be apart of a government run healthcare system. Even if you don't use roads, for instance, or schools, or whatever, you definitely benefit from living in a society that provides those things to the public as a whole. replies.author: @Revelwoodie
replies.text:
@RavenStorm332 Yes we pay taxes, sometimes tolls, and sometimes other fees (like parking) to maintain our transportation infrastructure.  It's called a diversified revenue stream.

Yes, economic models are "just theories."  So is gravity.  And while I'll grant that economics is a softer science than physics, if you're rejecting what that science tells you on the basis of preexisting ideology, I'm not sure why you're studying economics.

As far as "trying it out" is concerned, we already did try out the radical freedom, every-man-for-himself model.  It was called the Stone Age.

I'm not trying to be snarky (I think I'm just naturally snarky, lol), I'm just trying to urge you to question your position.

author: @GreatRedMenace
text:
I'm sorry, but you should really read 10:50, and what the BDS wants. It states 3 things: 1) "Ending the occupation and colonization of all Arab lands", which can mean both the West Bank and Gaza AND sovereign Israeli territory. They don't specify which lands they consider "colonized.

2) Recognize full equality between Arabs and Jews. Which is fine, but here's the catch:

3) Respecting and protecting the rights of all Palestinian Arab refugees to "return to their homes and properties as stipulated in UN resolution 194". A resolution from 1949.

Put the three of those aspects together, and you will notice why the BDS rejects saying there is a need for a two state solution, because what the BDS wants is to end the Jewish State, be it with one or two Arab states that replace it. The "return" of refugees, which they consider descendents of refugees included, would overnight end Jewish majority in Israel. Considering number 2, which forces the preservation of Israel's democratic rights to Arabs, it means the vast majority of the population would become Arab, thus ending the Jewish State.

In other words, supporting the BDS is a rejection of the Two State solution, and a rejection of the basis of UN resolution 242 that is the basis of all the peace process. They are essentially supporting the thesis of Hamas. This is why the first point, the "ending the occupation and colonization of all Arab lands", is associated with the Hamas thesis that Tel Aviv is also a colonization project and should be razed to the ground. At the very least, it should be returned as "Tell al Rabiya", whatever that is.

This is sneaky and full of dogwhistles of denying Jews the right for self determination, which means denying Jews a human right, being that inherently antisemitic. This is wrong, and I'm surprised you haven't noticed that, ThreeArrows.
